existed. What you seem to miss, though, is that together with this 
temperature changes, the Earth's fauna changed a lot as well. When an 
iteration of cold and warm Earth temperatures happen, most of the 
then-flowering species go extinct. 
So, the two important questions you need to ask yourself are:
 - Is a raise in temperature good or bad for us, humans? Increasing 
temperature has been linked to heavier and more frequent superstorms. In 
other parts it has led to extreme draught, destroying yields. It also 
endangers a lot of species that are important to many ecosystems we rely 
on. Bees f.e. are doing extremely bad and bees are extremely important for 
a lot of plants to procreate.
 - Do we humans affect or contribute to climate change in any way? Can we 
change that and decrease our impact? The majority of scientists agree that 
we do affect and have a negative impact on climate change.

So basically, what environmentalists try to do, is raise awareness for 
these two issues and try to convince people to try to change our impact.
What you, deniers, keep doing is boycotting our efforts. 

If required, I can accept that you don't care. But please stop trying to 
convince others to not care as well. You're doing no one or no thing a 
favor.

comments.text:
The government, in general, was prepared. One week prior to the storm, all 
people started working on their evacuation plans. Tacloban included. In all 
50 years of my life, like all Filipinos, I have never seen one of this 
magnitude. Who among us can define a "storm surge" prior to this? Even 
experts were clueless, proof that one meteorologist apparently died when 
she drowned after she was washed away by the surge. Veteran broadcasters, 
fishermen, farmers, etc. who have year in and out "tamed" their response 
and attitude to the regular 30-or-more typhoons per year got the biggest 
shock of their lives when they underestimated the devastating effects they 
were in for. All the money pouring in are useless unless they sre used to 
purchase food and supplies. Many gov't agencies advanced their stocks of 
rice, noodles, canned goods etc. to these places, They can't find those 
after the storm! And those who kept their stocks didn't have volunteers to 
repack and distribute. No cops, no firemen, no workers, nothing. Even they 
were victims, or maybe dead too.

I'm pissed at all these blaming, most of it coming from Filipinos 
themselves. If they could only grow a little more brain and try to 
understand the humongous difficult task ahead amid the havoc then maybe, we 
can go forward faster and rise again as a stronger nation, more resilient, 
much wiser, more compassionate, more mature.

comments.text:
Jack194343, this response is for you, as well as for everyone else here who 
has made comments regarding the so-called 'rich', the corporations, and 
people within the government, etc. While it is true that they are all to 
blame for a lot of the problems we human beings face in this era, and, we 
all have every right to be upset with them, they are not alone. Most 
everyone else who is not aware of the bigger picture, is an equal 
contributor. Also, we cannot continue to rely on others to make the changes 
necessary to fix things. Our whole system is broken. We must first begin at 
the personal level, with ourselves, then, work our way forward from there, 
but, only after we have made changes within our own lives that align with 
our values and principles. Tell me, everyone, how much are your daily food 
choices contributing to climate change? Do you eat animal 'products'? Do 
you eat a lot of packaged foods? Do you purchase bottled water? Do you buy 
a lot of food and/or non-food products stored in plastics and boxes? When 
you shop for groceries, do you use the plastic bags provided by the stores, 
or, do you use bio-degradable and compostable, re-usable bags? How much 
consumerism do you contribute to in your lives? How much waste do you 
contribute to in your lives? Do you use up unnecessary amounts of 
electricity, by not turning off lights in rooms you aren't in, or leaving 
other electronics on, when not in use? What about water? Do you use only 
what you need, or are you wasteful? Do you keep the water running the 
entire time you are in the shower? Do you leave it running while brushing 
your teeth, or washing your hands, when it is unnecessary to do so? How 
much about the effects of the way we live as individuals within modern, 
developed society, exactly, are all of you unaware of? Unless you have done 
very, very thorough research, have looked closely at the way you live on a 
day-to-day basis, have considered the situation earnestly, and, are doing 
everything in your power to reduce your own impact on the climate in your 
personal lives, then, I'm sorry if it upsets you, but, you're not much 
better than those you are inaccurately laying all of the blame on.

Everyone, and, I mean EVERYONE, needs to seriously reflect on the way they 
live, then, make the changes necessary in their personal lives to 
contribute as little as possible and practical, their solitary 
contributions to our collective impact on the climate, overall.

As a humanitarian, environmentalist, and vegan, I see the bigger picture, 
quite clearly, and I live a very frugal existence, for the betterment of 
all, which is something we all should be doing. Steps must be taken to 
reduce our impact on the climate in ALL areas of our lives, and, we must 
educate people on the leading human-caused effects on the climate, as well 
as teaching the importance of living more in balance with our Earth's 
natural systems, and reducing our impact on the environment as much as 
possible. If you are so against what the so- called 'rich', the 
corporations, and those who work in government are doing to negatively 
impact our climate, then, you need to look at how you may be contributing 
to climate change yourselves, and, change your lifestyle accordingly to 
match your values. Otherwise, your words are empty, meaningless, and, you 
are wasting your time. If you are not sincere, don't act as if you are, 
and, if you aren't in this for others, and are mostly just concerned with 
your own well being, and the well being of those you hold closest to you, 
emotionally, then you need to reflect on your mindset. Let's stop the 
nonsense and get our acts together, people! We've got a lot of work to do!

captions.text:
My country is being tested by this hellstorm
called super typhoon Haiyan. We remain uncertain

as to the full extent of the damage and devastation
as information trickles in in an agonizingly

slow manner because power lines and communication
lines are cut off and may take a while before

they are restored. The initial assessment
shows that Haiyan left a wake of massive destruction

that is unprecedented, unthinkable and horrific.
And the devastation is staggering. I struggle

to find words even for the images that we
see on the news coverage and I struggle to

find words to describe how I feel about the
losses. Up to this hour, I agonize, waiting

for word for the fate of my very own relatives.
What gives me renewed strength and great relief

is that my own brother has communicated to
us and he has survived the onslaught. I speak

for my delegation, but I speak for the countless
people who will no longer be able to speak

for themselves after perishing from the storm.
I speak also for those who have been orphaned

by the storm. I speak for those people now
racing against time to save survivors and

alleviate the suffering of the people affected.
We can take drastic action now to ensure that

we prevent a future where super typhoons become
a way of life. Can we ever attain the ultimate

objective of the convention - which is to
prevent dangerous and tropogenic interference

with a climate system. By failing to meet
the objective of the convention, we may have

ratified our own doom. We have to confront
the issue of loss and damage. Loss and damage

is a reality today across the world. We cannot
solve climate change when we seek to spew

more emissions. In solidarity with my countrymen
who are struggling to find food back home,

and with my brother who has not had food for
the last three days, with all due respect,

Mr. President - and I mean no disrespect for
your kind hospitality - I will now commence

a voluntary fasting for the climate. This
means I will voluntarily refrain from eating

food during this cop until a meaning outcome
is in sight. Until concrete pledges have been

made to ensure mobilization of resources for
the green climate fund. We cannot afford cop

with an empty GCF. Until the promise of an
operalization of a loss and damage mechanism

has been fulfilled. Until there is a assurance
and financial adaptation. Until we see real

ambition on climate action in accordance with
the principles we have so upheld. Mr. President,

this process has been called a farce. It has
been called an annual carbon intensive gathering

of useless frequent fliers. It has also been
called saving tomorrow today. We can fix this.
We can stop

this madness. (Applause) Thank you Philippines
for your great speech. It’s always hard

to attribute a single weather event to climate
change, but we know that science is also clear

that climate change will mean more intense
typhoons, potentially. Even if we cannot attribute

Haiyan to climate change directly, my country
refuses to accept a future where super typhoons
will become a regular fixture.

title: Emotional Typhoon Haiyan Speech By Philippines Delegate
